page.title: 15NETHERTON CHAPEL
page.content: Netherton Chapel,now a ruin,was built in the late twelfth century.It is of interest architecturally and is maintained in its present condition by the farmer on whose land it stands.The north doorway of the nave is a fine example of Norman craftmanship.The arch with heeled jam shafts with carved capitals is of two orders externally,the outer with chevron and lozenge.There is a carved tympanum which stood over the south door.The east window,a sigle light with a cusped head and ribbed arch is believed to be thirteenth century;so too is the lancet between the two windows in the south wall.Rebates can be seen for shutters.There is a plain, narrow round-headed light probably from an earlier chapel.
